question: Get rid of this scum.
answer: Did we get it?

question: We got it. On your feet.
answer: I want to sleep. Can I sleep here.

question: Walk, just walk. Start walking.
answer: I'm walking.

question: Talking's good, walking's better.
answer: Sleeping's better. Are you all right Ethan. What's wrong with you?

question: If you're gonna do this again Claire, It's not gonna be on my watch.
answer: Oh yeah?

question: Look to your right, then back to me. There's a camera built right into the bridge. Whatever you see it sees and transmits it back here. Can you hear me?
answer: Of course I can hear you.

question: No, in your...ear piece. You have a lovely smile . Can you hear me now?
answer: Loud and clear.

question: What's going on?
answer: I don't know.

question: Why don't you take a look?
answer: Jack...that's spying.

question: That's what we do isn't it?
answer: Jack you're so wicked.

question: Too wicked to have a drink later?
answer: I think I might just take that look.

question: Yeah, well, Jim, fact is I've got more than ninety days leave coming.
answer: A hundred and sixty-seven, I think it is. Take it all, if you want. After this one.

question: I thought I'd take some now.
answer: What the hell's made you decide to take your leave at the worst possible time? Claire's in a weird mood too.

question: Oh? What's the problem?
answer: I don't know, I had to go to Chicago again. You were in Kiev. You tell me.

question: Tell you what?
answer: When you started noticing your short term memory loss. What the problem was you and Claire had in Kiev?

question: What problem?
answer: Ah, God, forget it. What are we talking burnout here?

question: I guess.
answer: Ethan, you can't burn out.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I can't afford it. And because you'd burn up before you'd burn out.

question: How was Chicago?
answer: Wonderful. Ran into a convention of auto dealers at the Drake Hotel. You hear the one about the astronaut who comes back from the first manned flight to Mars after two years? His wife's got a year old kid. So he says "All right. Who was it? My friend Harry?" She says no. "Oh, it was my friend Sammy." She says it wasn't Sammy. "Oh, I suppose it was my friend Lou." "No, what's the matter, don't you think I have any friends of my own?!" Boy, you really are grim. Come here, take a look. Beyond Charles Bridge there is our Embassy. See it? Tomorrow night, if anything goes wrong, this guy will steal the names of our agents in every country all over Eastern Europe. Up for grabs to the highest bidders -- third world terrorists, arms dealers, drug lords -- any and everybody who'd love to get rid of long term coverts like us, and some very dear friends among them. If they're exposed, they'll be executed. Come over here. Take a lock at this.

question: You're going to use Walter?
answer: He's our guy.

question: Isn't he chairing the Armed Services hearing?
answer: Not this week. This week he's flyfishing at the Oughterard Slough in County Kildare, with one of our best Irish guides.

question: He won't be back in a hurry?
answer: No, not in a hurry. What do you think? You think the plot'll work?

question: Sure. If the main character does.
answer: If you were me, Ethan, who would you trust to make him believable?

question: No, were going to recover the disk, understand?! Now move!
answer: Where are you?

question: About two hundred yards from the bridge.
answer: Theyre covering this frequency, Ethan. Cut all radio communications. Repeat. Cut all radio communications.

question: Central Europe. Unsecured. Bravo Echo one one.
answer: This is Kittridge.

question: Go secure.
answer: Go ahead.

question: Theyre dead.
answer: Whos dead?

question: My team. Claire, Jack, even Jim - - Hannah, maybe, I -- dont know
answer: Are you damaged?

question: They knew we were coming. Golitsyns dead too. The disk is gone.
answer: Are you intact?

question: Do you read me? The list is in the open!
answer: Let's just bring you in safely, and then we'll worry about that, okay? Were you followed?

question: I dont think so.
answer: Dont think, be sure. Are you clean?

question: Yes.
answer: Location green. One hour. Ill be there myself.

question: Youre in Prague?
answer: Heard a lot about you, Hunt. Dont disappoint me.

question: No sir.
answer: One hour. I can't tell you how sorry I am. I know how much Jim in particular meant to you, Ethan. Personally as well as professionally.

question: Yeah.
answer: Passport, visas - you know the drill. We'll work the exfiltration thru Canada, debrief you at Langley. Throw the Prague police a bone, you know toss them a few suspects. Follow me?

question: Yeah. I follow you.
answer: We've lost enough agents for one night.

question: You mean I've lost enough agents for one night.
answer: You seem hell bent on blaming yourself, Ethan.

question: Who else is left?
answer: Yes. I see your point.

question: Why was there another team?
answer: What?

question: Of IMF agents. At the Embassy. Tonight.
answer: I don't quite follow you.

question: Let's see if you can follow me around this room. The drunk Russians on the embankment at 7 and 8 o'clock...The couple waltzing around me at the Embassy at 9 and 11. The waiter behind Hannah at the top of the staircase - Bowtie, 12 o'clock. The other IMF team. You're worried about me. Why?
answer: You're right. Maybe this'll save some time. For a little over two years now we've been spotting serious blowback in IMF operations. We have a penetration. The other day we decoded a message on the Internet from a Czech we know as "Max."

question: The arms dealer.
answer: That's right. Max, it seems, has two unique gifts -- a capacity for anonymity and for corrupting susceptible agents. This time he's gotten to someone on the inside - he's put himself in a position to buy our NOC list. An operation he referred to as "Job 314". The job he thought Golitsyn was doing tonight.

question: But the list Golitsyn stole was a decoy.
answer: Correct the actual list is safe at Langley. "Golitsyn" was a lightning rod, one of ours.

question: This whole operation was a molehunt.
answer: Yes, the mole's deep inside. And -- like you said. You survived. I want to show you something, Ethan. Since your father's death, your family's farm has been in sub-chapter S and now, suddenly, they're flush with over a hundred and twenty grand in the bank. Dad's illness was supposed to have wiped out the bank account -- dying slowly in America after all, can be a very expensive proposition Ethan. So, why don't we go quietly out of here onto the plane...

question: How about if we just go quietly into the bathroom and I wash your mouth out with soap - you pathetic button down bureaucratic asshole.
answer: Ethan, I can understand you're very upset.

question: Kitteridge, you've never seen me very upset.
answer: All right, enough is enough Hunt. You've bribed, cajoled, killed - and relied on intimate loyalties to get away with it. You're determined to shake hands with the devil and I'm going to make sure you do it in hell.

question: What are you doing here?!
answer: Ethan -- Ethan, it's okay. It's Claire. Ethan what's wrong with you?

question: Don't move. You were in the car!
answer: I wasn't. I heard that Jim was in trouble on the radio. He said someone was...

question: Shut up! I saw you. You were in the car.
answer: No, I got out of the car and I ran to the bridge.

question: Don't give me that! I was on the bridge.
answer: What happened to Jim?

question: There was nobody on the bridge.
answer: What happened to Jim?

question: Dead. Dead. Dead! Wake up, Claire! Jim's dead, they're dead. They're all dead!
answer: They're dead. Jim's dead.

question: Take off your coat.
answer: What?

question: Take off your God damn coat! Where were you?
answer: I walked away. He said abort. He was gone so I walked away.

question: That was four hours ago! Who sent you? Did they send you here?
answer: Who is "they?"

question: Did they send you...Did they send you?
answer: Who is they, who is they?

question: Who sent you?! Who sent you?
answer: No one sent me! We're supposed to be back here at four o'clock, four o'clock, if we abort, we don't return here until four o'clock, 0-four hundred, four am, four o'clock --! Why haven't they brought us in yet?

question: I've been disavowed. They think I killed Jim and everyone else. Somehow a hundred thousand dollars found its way into my parents' bank account. Kittridge assumes I'm a mole they've been tracing and I've been in the employ of an arms dealer, Max, for the last two years, to get him our NOC list.
answer: What are you going to do?

question: I'm going to get it for him. Whoever the mole is, I think goes by the name of Job, at least part of the time. 1 can't find him, but if he knows 1 have the NOC list, he'll find me.
answer: Ethan, you're not making sense. Let me go in and talk to Kittridge. I'm going to tell him you had nothing to do...

question: Claire, Claire, Claire, if you're not dead, he's going to assume you're with me.
answer: The message is for Job.

question: I'm going to answer it. Excuse me, could I trouble you for a match?
answer: Would you remove your hat please?

question: Why?
answer: You wish to meet Max? This is the price of admission.

question: I thought I was going to see Max.
answer: You misunderstood. No one sees Max.

question: Then what am I doing here?
answer: Allowing Max to see you and hear what you've got to say.

question: I don't communicate very well through a shroud.
answer: If Max doesn't like what you have to say, you'll be wearing that shroud indefinitely.

question: I'm willing to take the chance.
answer: Very well.

question: Who are you and what are you doing here?
answer: I need one hundred thousand dollars.

question: Really? And you thought if you simply showed up I might give it to you?
answer: Why not? You gave Job a hundred and twenty five thousand.

question: The penny drops. You are not Job. Yes, Job is not given to quoting Scripture in his communications. And there was its tone -- aggressive but playful. Job is not playful. So you're something of a paradox.
answer: That depends.

question: On what?
answer: Whether you like a paradox. I want a hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

question: It's quite out of the question.
answer: The disk Job sold you is worthless. It's bait, part of an internal molehunt.

question: And how might you know that? Are you another Company man?
answer: Like Job?

question: Ah, but, we're asking about you.
answer: I'm NOC. Was. Now disavowed.

question: Why, may I ask?
answer: That's the question I want to ask Job.

question: I don't know Job any more than he knows me.
answer: Even so, I'm sure you could arrange an introduction.

question: Why should I?
answer: Because I can deliver the actual NOC list. The one you have is not only worthless, it's certain to be equipped with a homing device to pinpoint your exact location.

question: It's easy to say the disk is worthless when you say I can't look at the information and see if it's worthless. Not a tenable position, sir.
answer: Okay, boot it up and in anywhere from thirty seconds to ten minutes you're gonna have Virginia farm boys hopping around you like jackrabbits.

question: Mm - Hmmm...
answer: Tell you what. How good's the RF scanner you used in the car?

question: Very good.
answer: Okay, use it. But I suggest pack up first.

question: Twenty-six, twenty-seven. So far so good.
answer: That's not so good for you, my friend.

question: Thirty-two and change.
answer: Doesn't mean it's a signal. Could just be the hard drive heating up.

question: Oh dear, Gunther will never let me use one of his apartments again. Phew, sorry I doubted you, dear boy. You're a good sport. Do accept the compliment.
answer: Thanks, Max. Or is it Maxine?

question: I don't have to tell you what a comfort anonymity can be in my profession -- like a warm blanket. My deal with Job was subject to a successful boot scan. Obviously it didn't pass muster. Deal's off.
answer: What was your deal with Job?

question: Six million dollars. I'll give you the same. But I want the complete list now, not just Eastern Europe. I won't do this piecemeal, it's too dangerous. I want the entire list, the true name of every non-official cover agent throughout the world.
answer: Ten million. Ten million in negotiable U.S. Treasury certificates, in bearer form, coupons attached. And one more thing -- your personal assurance that Job will be at the exchange.

question: Done. Bring it to me in London. I want it by the end of the week.
answer: How will you make sure Job will be there?

question: How will you make sure I'll have the list in three days? It's been a delight. Now where can I drop you dear boy?
answer: I'm not being dropped anywhere without my money.

question: I'm going to have to front you personally. Don't lose that money without losing your life.
answer: I wouldn't dream of it.

question: The man's gone black, Barnes. He's under until he decides to surface.
answer: Look we can use someone from the Embassy and we can get the local authorities involved. Close off his transportation.

question: What can we do, Barnes? Put a guy at the airport? How many identities do you think Hunt has? How many times has he slipped past custom, in how many countries? These guys are trained to be ghosts. We taught them how to do it, for Christ's sake!
answer: So what do you suggest?

question: Max made a deal with you?
answer: I deliver the NOC list, Max delivers Job.

question: We've got seventy-five rounds for your Glock 9, but only twenty for the Sig Sauer, one pair of Visco glasses with monitor, plenty of passports. You said it yourself -- if I'm not dead, I'm with you.
answer: You're sure about this?

question: Jim was my husband. I want to know who killed him. I want to get the son of a bitch who did this.
answer: We need help, and we don't have time. They have to be local.

question: What kind of help?
answer: Simple game. Four players. Exfil opens the pocket -- -- cyber ops lifts the wallet.

question: Simple game. Four players. Exfil opens the pocket -- -- cyber ops lifts the wallet.
answer: Bank?

question: IMF mainframe.
answer: Where exactly is it?

question: I don't know. This I don't know.
answer: This doesn't sound like the Luther Stickell I've heard of. What'd they used to call you? The Net Ranger? Phineas Phreak? The only man alive who actually hacked NATO Ghostcom.

question: There was never any physical evidence that I had anything to do with that.. that.. With that exceptional piece of work.
answer: You don't know what you're missing. This is the Mt. Everest of hacks.

question: May I come in?
answer: Sure...

question: It's cash. And a second passport. If anything goes wrong when we're inside, if you sense even the slightest deviation don't look over your shoulder, you walk away - you hear me? Just walk away.
answer: You don't think we're going to make it.

question: I didn't say that.
answer: You didn't have to.........

question: I just need you to be safe.
answer: What about you?

question: What about me - Jim called an abort - I didn't comply. I lost the team. I just need you to be safe.
answer: I wish I'd never laid eyes on you..

question: He's at the vault - get moving! 1 yellow, 2 yellows...Toast!
answer: ETHAN, still hanging upside down, has refused. KRIEGER demands again.

question: You're not moving!
answer: ETHAN is hoisted up.

question: Phew! NOC list.
answer: ETHAN has the diskette in his mouth. KRIEGER leans down and takes it. He drops the knife.

question: Think, for Christ's sake, you guys are mired in detail, open your minds, it's gotta be staring us in the face! What does Ethan Hunt want?!
answer: Same thing he wanted in Prague! Same thing he's always wanted! The NOC list!

question: Okay! And where is the list vulnerable? Other than here. Kittridge, yup? You and I know about this -- and that's where it stops. Understand? It never happened.
answer: What about him...?

question: Stay out of this.
answer: Don't you mean this?

question: That's not it. That's not the list.
answer: What's the matter, you don't know this trick? Where did it go?! It's GONE! But not too far! I know what you're thinking, Krieger. You're thinking, back in the computer room -- I was up here -- he was down there -- . He was carrying two discs. So hard to keep track of these things.

question: Where is it?
answer: I thought you had it! Do you actually think I'd let you have the NOC list?

question: Krieger did have the NOC list.
answer: Now I want you to hold onto it.

question: What makes you trust me?
answer: Because if you knew what you were getting into, you never would have done it.

question: I'm not letting this list get out in the open.
answer: Exactly, that's your job. Tomorrow on the train, you can't let this list get out into the open. What's the range of this thing?

question: It's hard to tell. I'm gonna have to be close.
answer: I'll get you close.

question: Kittridge...
answer: Bastard!

question: Don't...don't touch me...
answer: What are you going to do?

question: He's expecting my call. I'm going to the station... And I'm going to call him.
answer: Kittridge.

question: I see you've been out visiting the folks.
answer: It's Hunt. What do you need for a pinpoint? Been watching a little T.V., have you?

question: Hauling Mom off to jail in shackles was an especially nice touch.
answer: Get MI5. Ethan, I want to reassure you that my first order of business after you come in is to get these ridiculous charges against your family dropped and eliminated completely from their files. Come in now, we can plea down the charges against you as well.

question: Can I ask you something, Kittridge?
answer: Certainly Ethan.

question: If you're dealing with someone who's crushed, stabbed, shot and detonated five members of his own IMF team, how devastated do you think you're going to make him by marching Ma and Uncle Donald down to the county courthouse?
answer: I don't know, Ethan. Suppose you tell me?

question: You're a hard man to catch up with. ..the next day I managed to drag myself to the safe house, must've just missed you..anyway, I checked our aliases.
answer: - and picked us up in the States -

question: - but you left before I could get there and I could check just so many places..
answer: Yeah, smaller countries don't computerize customs records -

question: - so I watched Europe. Once you showed up in England..it was easy.
answer: You knew I liked the rentals at Liverpool Street.

question: Hey, I showed 'em to you!
answer: I remember.. Jim, who do you think you're kidding? A doctor's gotta look at that. You can't sit up straight.

question: I can sit up straight. I just can't..sit up straight very well. It's not important! I saw who shot me. Ethan, I saw the mole. It was Kittridge. Kittridge!
answer: Kitteridge. Oh my god! Kittridge is the mole?

question: Yeah.
answer: How did Kittridge do it?..

question: Why, Jim? Why?
answer: ..when you think about it, Ethan, it was inevitable..no more Cold War. No more secrets you keep from everyone but yourself, operations you answer to no one but yourself. Then one morning you wake up and find out the President of the United States is running the country - without your permission. The son-of-a- bitch! How dare he? You realize its over, youre an obsolete piece of hardware not worth upgrading, youve got a lousy marriage and sixty-two grand a year. Kittridge, well go after that no good son-of-a-bitch, big time!

question: We dont have to, Jim. Hell come after us.
answer: Whats going to make him do that?

question: What he didnt get in Prague. The NOC list.
answer: Jesus, Ethan. Good for you.

question: A meeting tomorrow on the TGV, enroute to Paris.
answer: Tight security. No guns. Real plus.

question: If I supposedly deliver the NOC list to Max, Max has agreed to deliver Job to me. Ill have Claire and Luther Stickell with me on the train. Marcel Krieger will have helicopter transport waiting in Paris. Jim...?
answer: I was sitting in a cafe waiting for you and suddenly there she was, standing in the rain just outside the safe house..alive and beautiful..and thinking Im dead and gone. God knows what shes had to do forget about me to keep going and get the job done, I.. - no. She cant know about me. No one can. Not til this is over. Theres too much at stake, Ethan.

question: Youre probably right.
answer: I usually am.

question: Once we leave the safehouse, get in there and crash. Ill call you from Paris.
answer: You got it.

question: And get a doctor.
answer: Good luck.

question: What happened?
answer: I sent the message to Max. Were on for tomorrow.

question: Okay...
answer: Is this the only way?

question: This wasnt what we discussed.
answer: My apologies Max. Couldnt be helped. Theres a piece of black cloth under your seat. Tear it away and youll find the disk.

question: Ha, dear boy! I do hope this doesnt prelude a meeting in private.
answer: It doesnt, dear girl. as long as you tell me where the money is.

question: The possibility alone is worth ten million. Baggage car, rack 3. Silver briefcase. Combination 314.
answer: What about Job?

question: Only four more cars.
answer: And if we dont find him - well search the whole train again.

question: Whats Hunt doing on the TGV?
answer: High speed train. No-one gets on. No- one gets off. High security. Good place for a pass off to Max.

question: But why tell us?
answer: Hes putting on a show, Barnes.

question: What kind of show.
answer: I dont know. It didnt say on the tickets.

question: Hes in the baggage car. Whats the problem.
answer: Connection denied.

question: Try it again.
answer: Its not working.

question: Is something wrong with the phone? Well is something wrong with the batteries?
answer: I always check the batteries.

question: Keep counting Claire.
answer: It was me. I did it.

question: Satisfied?
answer: All ten million.

question: Claire...Hey...
answer: This stuff is so sticky.

question: Claire.
answer: Its all right, Ethan..youll bring me back...wont you...

question: Reach your folks? How they feeling?
answer: About what?

question: The official apology from the Justice Department, the VIP treatment, you know, the whole nine yards.
answer: Well my Mother was a little confused about how the DEA could mistake her and Uncle Donald for a couple of dope smugglers in the Florida keys.

question: Cheers.
answer: Here's to you, Luther. To being off the disavowed list.

question: Hey, I'm the flavour of the month!
answer: You're more than that, Luther. They were mistaken about you and they're trying to show you they know it. They want you back in.

question: Sure. They want me back in so I won't break in! They still can't figure out how we did it.
answer: You didn't tell 'em at the debriefing?

question: I figured I'd let 'em reinstate my back pay, give me a promotion, check out my office at Langley and then, maybe, talk about it.
answer: It's all one big negotiation, isn't it?

question: Why don't you come back with me?
answer: Just don't know why I'd be doing it.

question: You really liked Phelps, didn't you?
answer: He was a good guy for a long, long time. Just - not long enough. Gotta catch my flight.. So. How's it feel being a solid citizen again?

question: Oh man...I don't know. I'm gonna miss being disreputable.
answer: Well, Luther - if it makes you feel any better I'll always think of you that way.
